docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text:
[cite_start]Students, researchers, and developers often struggle to create proper documentation for their software projects[cite: 4]. [cite_start]Writing project descriptions and LaTeX reports manually takes significant time and effort[cite: 5].

  • [cite_start]Student Struggles: Over 65% of CS students find writing documentation harder than writing code[cite: 7].
  • [cite_start]Industry Reality: Software engineers spend 25-30% of their time on documentation[cite: 8].
  • [cite_start]Existing Tools: Most tools are too technical or only generate simple comments, lacking full reports or LaTeX-formatted academic content[cite: 10].

docs.title: The Solution
docs.text:
[cite_start]AutoDoc Writer is a desktop-style application that connects to your GitHub account to solve this[cite: 12, 16]. Whenever you push new code, the software reads the changes and automatically generates: * Clear documentation * Research-style paragraphs * [cite_start]LaTeX code [cite: 17]

[cite_start]It removes the burden of manual reporting, helping you produce clean, professional writeups effortlessly[cite: 18].

docs.title: Technical Architecture
docs.text: [cite_start]AutoDoc Writer is built using the Electron + React + Python stack, designed for a seamless desktop experience[cite: 144].

docs.title: Tech Stack
docs.text: Component Technology Description Application Shell Electron (Node.js) [cite_start]Handles the desktop window and file system access[cite: 145]. Frontend (UI) React + TypeScript [cite_start]Built with Tailwind CSS for the visible interface[cite: 146]. Backend (Logic) Python (FastAPI) [cite_start]Runs locally to handle logic and API requests[cite: 147]. AI/ML Google Generative AI [cite_start]Utilizes google-generativeai (or OpenAI) for text generation[cite: 148]. Database SQLite [cite_start]Uses SQLAlchemy to store user settings and cached docs locally[cite: 149]. GitHub API PyGithub [cite_start]Manages repository fetching and commit tracking[cite: 148].

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
• [cite_start]OAuth 2.0: Secure login via GitHub; no password storage[cite: 71, 72].
  • [cite_start]Local Storage: Outputs are stored locally on the user's machine rather than external servers[cite: 73, 138].

docs.title: A. GitHub Integration
docs.text:
[cite_start]Description: Establishes a secure connection between the app and your version control system[cite: 80].

  • [cite_start]Login: Uses GitHub OAuth for secure login without storing passwords[cite: 22, 72].
  • [cite_start]Monitoring: Automatically fetches user repositories and allows enabling/disabling monitoring for each[cite: 23, 24].
  • [cite_start]Detection: Detects new commits or push events to trigger documentation generation[cite: 25].

docs.title: B. AI-Powered Documentation
docs.text:
[cite_start]Description: The core engine that transforms code logic into three distinct types of content[cite: 89].

  1. [cite_start]Simple Code Explanation: Plain English descriptions of updated functions, classes, or files[cite: 30].
  2. [cite_start]Research/Thesis Paragraphs: Academically formatted paragraphs suitable for reports and thesis writing[cite: 32].
  3. [cite_start]LaTeX Code Generation: Generates LaTeX environments ready for editors like Overleaf[cite: 33, 34].

docs.title: C. Documentation Viewer
docs.text: [cite_start]A clean interface to view and verify generated text[cite: 37, 96]. * [cite_start]Tab-based Output: Switch between "Plain Text," "Research Style," and "LaTeX" modes [cite: 39, 41-43]. * [cite_start]Download Options: Save outputs in your preferred format[cite: 44].

docs.title: D. Repository Monitoring Dashboard
docs.text: [cite_start]A central hub displaying all connected repositories with "Active" or "Inactive" status indicators[cite: 45, 46]. [cite_start]It provides a real-time feed of commit activity[cite: 46].

docs.title: E. Commit Activity Tracking
docs.text: [cite_start]Logs specific updates made by the user[cite: 109]. * [cite_start]Displays repository name, timestamp, and commit messages[cite: 49]. * [cite_start]Allows manual triggering of documentation generation for past commits[cite: 112].

docs.title: F. Offline-Ready Desktop Experience
docs.text: [cite_start]Runs as a desktop-style web app[cite: 51]. * [cite_start]Local Caching: Browses locally cached writeups even without an internet connection[cite: 52, 119]. * [cite_start]Responsive: Smooth, lightweight UI[cite: 52].

docs.title: G. Export & Sharing
docs.text: [cite_start]Extract generated documentation for external use[cite: 129]. * [cite_start]Formats: Export as Markdown, PDF, LaTeX, or Plain Text [cite: 60-67]. * [cite_start]One-Click Copy: Quickly paste text into other editors[cite: 68].

docs.title: Sprint 1: Foundation & Connectivity
docs.text:
• [cite_start]Focus: UI Skeleton, Basic GitHub Auth, Repository Fetching[cite: 154].
  • [cite_start]Status: Setup Electron + React environment and FastAPI server[cite: 177, 181].

docs.title: Sprint 2: The Intelligence Core
docs.text:
• [cite_start]Focus: AI Integration (Basic Summary) and Active Monitoring toggle[cite: 155].
  • [cite_start]Key Feature: "Detect New Commits" polling logic[cite: 197].

docs.title: Sprint 3: Heavy Lifting (Crunch Sprint)
docs.text:
• [cite_start]Focus: Deep Logic (LaTeX/Research generation) and Export options[cite: 157].
  • Key Tasks:
    • [cite_start]Test LaTeX in Overleaf[cite: 203].
    • [cite_start]Implement "Diff Reading" to analyze only changed files[cite: 217].

docs.title: Sprint 4: Polish & Offline Capability
docs.text:
• [cite_start]Focus: Offline Mode (Caching), Settings, and Packaging[cite: 159].
  • [cite_start]Key Feature: Load data from local cache if API fails[cite: 227].

docs.title: Sprint 5: Final Demo Prep
docs.text:
• [cite_start]Focus: Full Product Demo and Bug Bash[cite: 160].
  • [cite_start]Final Step: Create installer (.exe/.dmg) using electron-builder[cite: 238].
